required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Postpartum Quality of Recovery & Maternal Satisfaction After C/S
clinical_study.official_title: Relationship Between Patient Reported Postpartum Quality of Recovery and Maternal Satisfaction After Cesarean Delivery: A Prospective Observational Study

brief_summary.textblock: Measuring patient-oriented outcomes and satisfaction is important to guide meaningful changes in obstetric anesthesia care. Quality of Recovery (QoR) scores are patient rated measures, which provide a global measure of recovery after surgery. They go beyond the measure of physiological variables to include, physical, cognitive, emotive and functional outcomes. Satisfaction, in addition to QoR scores after anaesthesia is an important quality marker. Measuring satisfaction after the birth of a child is a complex and emotive subject. Understanding the factors that can influence maternal satisfaction may improve patient-centred care. Studies have shown that despite favorable clinical outcomes, many women undergoing caesarean deliveries continue to have poor experience with anaesthesia. These poor experiences go beyond inadequate pain control; many are due to poor communication with clinicians, lack of involvement in decision making, lack of provision of high quality education and information and a feeling of inadequate choice and control relating to decisions of the birth of their babies. In non-obstetric studies, satisfaction after anaesthesia has consistently been shown to be dependent on the information patient has received along with the quality of the communication and the quality of the anaesthetist-patient relationship.

primary_outcome.description: Quality of recovery will be measured using the obstetric quality of recovery score (ObsQoR-11). This is a 11-item, multidimensional recovery scoring tool, which has been validated in this population

primary_outcome.measure: Maternal Satisfaction Scale for Cesarean Section (MSSCS)
primary_outcome.description: This 22 item questionnaire measures satisfaction with the anaesthetic, needle insertion, side effects and the theatre atmosphere. Items are rated on a 7-point likert scale from strongly disagree to strongly agree.
First open ended question assessing: "What aspects of your care were you most satisfied with?"
Second open ended question assessing: "What aspects of your care were you most dissatisfied with?"
Third and last open ended question assessing: "Do you have any suggestions on what would improve your satisfaction?"

secondary_outcome.description: Total frequency of gravidity and preterm
Patient age in years
Gestational age in total weeks and days
Patient height measured in centimeters
Patient weight measured in kilograms
Result of singleton, twins, or other
APGAR scores at 1 minute and minutes
Neonatal birthweight measured in grams
American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status classification system ranging from 1 to 6
Including: pregnancy induced HTN, pre-eclampsia, gestational diabetes, anemia, hyperemesis, cholestasis, and other.
Including any medical conditions that do not constitute a pregnancy medical condition
Neuraxial agents and dosage administered prior and during the cesarean section procedure.
Intraoperative anxiolytics drug and dose administered prior and during the cesarean section procedure.
Time in military time format
Classified as: scheduled, STAT, P1, or P2
Reason for cesarean delivery
Indicated as: spontaneous, augmented, or induction of labour
Length of hours for both first stage and second stage
Indicated as: epidural/CSE/DPE, Entonox, M&G, or other
Indicated as: hypotension, shivering, nausea, vomiting, itch, failed neuraxial, or other.
Blood loss measured in milliliters.
Any medical complication indicated after the caesarean delivery.

study_pop.textblock: All women above the age of 19 years old whom underwent a caesarean section will be eligible to participate. Women will be surveyed at 24 hours after their cesarean section. Data will be collected by means of validated paper questionnaires administered in person by a study investigator that is not part of clinical care.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Fluent English speaker
- Older than 19 years of age
- Received a cesarean delivery
- Received a cesarean delivery 24-48 hours prior to time of recruitment
Exclusion Criteria:
- Non-English speaker
- Below the age of 19 years
- Did not receive a cesarean delivery
- Received a cesarean delivery more than 48hrs after time of recruitment
